column5: Does Canada allow the possession of the flare pistols??? Thanks

Not sure of the answer. I always have flares and have been checked by OPP on LOW three times in the last 20 years or so. They never had a concern. We have traditionally shot them off on July 1 every year. Kids always loved it when they were younger. I never needed them myself but have responded twice to people who needed help. Nothing serious just ended up towing them in.

Sounds like it may be up to the discretion of the inspecting officer.If it resembles a regular firearm or has characteristics of a regular firearm it may be disallowed. I would buy some regular flares and leave the flare gun at home.
Canadian Tire in Dryden has these for salehttp://www.canadiantire.ca/en/pdp/12...-0790054p.html
I know in the past, that we were not allowed to have them in the boat when crossing over the line on Lake Erie, but they started allowing them last year.

In the past I've been asked if I had a flare gun when crossing the border. The answer was "no" so we moved on to the next question. I've never checked on the law, but there has to be a reason they are asking.
It's been a few years (less than 15), but I communicated with Canada Officials and they said as long as the flare gun was not used in the commmision of a crime, no problem.

My understanding is flare guns are now allowed as long as the flare shell is not loaded into the gun. So in other words it's legal to carry the common flare gun kit with the flare shells in the kit but not actually loaded into the gun chamber.
